#Text=THE ADVENTURE OF THE SOLITARY CYCLIST
#Text=From the years 1894 to 1901 inclusive , Mr. Sherlock Holmes was a very busy man .

#Text=It is safe to say that there was no public case of any difficulty in which he was not consulted during those eight years , and there were hundreds of private cases , some of them of the most intricate and extraordinary character , in which he played a prominent part .
#Text=Many startling successes and a few unavoidable failures were the outcome of this long period of continuous work .

#Text=As I have preserved very full notes of all these cases , and was myself personally engaged in many of them , it may be imagined that it is no easy task to know which I should select to lay before the public .

#Text=I shall , however , preserve my former rule , and give the preference to those cases which derive their interest not so much from the brutality of the crime as from the ingenuity and dramatic quality of the solution .

#Text=For this reason I will now lay before the reader the facts connected with Miss Violet Smith , the solitary cyclist of Charlington , and the curious sequel of our investigation , which culminated in unexpected tragedy .

#Text=It is true that the circumstance did not admit of any striking illustration of those powers for which my friend was famous , but there were some points about the case which made it stand out in those long records of crime from which I gather the material for these little narratives .
#Text=On referring to my notebook for the year 1895 , I find that it was upon Saturday , the 23rd of April , that we first heard of Miss Violet Smith .

#Text=Her visit was , I remember , extremely unwelcome to Holmes , for he was immersed at the moment in a very abstruse and complicated problem concerning the peculiar persecution to which John Vincent Harden , the well-known tobacco millionaire , had been subjected .
#Text=My friend , who loved above all things precision and concentration of thought , resented anything which distracted his attention from the matter in hand .

#Text=And yet , without a harshness which was foreign to his nature , it was impossible to refuse to listen to the story of the young and beautiful woman , tall , graceful , and queenly , who presented herself at Baker Street late in the evening , and implored his assistance and advice .

#Text=It was vain to urge that his time was already fully occupied , for the young lady had come with the determination to tell her story , and it was evident that nothing short of force could get her out of the room until she had done so .
#Text=With a resigned air and a somewhat weary smile , Holmes begged the beautiful intruder to take a seat , and to inform us what it was that was troubling her .
#Text=“ At least it cannot be your health , ” said he , as his keen eyes darted over her , “ so ardent a bicyclist must be full of energy . ”
#Text=She glanced down in surprise at her own feet , and I observed the slight roughening of the side of the sole caused by the friction of the edge of the pedal .
#Text=“ Yes , I bicycle a good deal , Mr. Holmes , and that has something to do with my visit to you to-day . ”
#Text=My friend took the lady ’s ungloved hand , and examined it with as close an attention and as little sentiment as a scientist would show to a specimen .
#Text=“ You will excuse me , I am sure .
#Text=It is my business , ” said he , as he dropped it . “ I nearly fell into the error of supposing that you were typewriting .
#Text=Of course , it is obvious that it is music .
#Text=You observe the spatulate finger-ends , Watson , which is common to both professions ?
#Text=There is a spirituality about the face , however ” — she gently turned it towards the light — “ which the typewriter does not generate .
#Text=This lady is a musician . ”
#Text=“ Yes , Mr. Holmes , I teach music . ”
#Text=“ In the country , I presume , from your complexion . ”
#Text=“ Yes , sir , near Farnham , on the borders of Surrey . ”
#Text=“ A beautiful neighbourhood , and full of the most interesting associations .
#Text=You remember , Watson , that it was near there that we took Archie Stamford , the forger .
#Text=Now , Miss Violet , what has happened to you , near Farnham , on the borders of Surrey ? ”
#Text=The young lady , with great clearness and composure , made the following curious statement :
#Text=“ My father is dead , Mr. Holmes .
#Text=He was James Smith , who conducted the orchestra at the old Imperial Theatre .
#Text=My mother and I were left without a relation in the world except one uncle , Ralph Smith , who went to Africa twenty-five years ago , and we have never had a word from him since .
#Text=When father died , we were left very poor , but one day we were told that there was an advertisement in The Times , inquiring for our whereabouts .
#Text=You can imagine how excited we were , for we thought that someone had left us a fortune .
#Text=We went at once to the lawyer whose name was given in the paper .
#Text=There we met two gentlemen , Mr. Carruthers and Mr. Woodley , who were home on a visit from South Africa .

#Text=They said that my uncle was a friend of theirs , that he had died some months before in great poverty in Johannesburg , and that he had asked them with his last breath to hunt up his relations , and see that they were in no want .

#Text=It seemed strange to us that Uncle Ralph , who took no notice of us when he was alive , should be so careful to look after us when he was dead , but Mr. Carruthers explained that the reason was that my uncle had just heard of the death of his brother , and so felt responsible for our fate . ”
